metadata.description: Regional efficiency factor variations to account for different technology mixes, climate, and development levels
metadata.methodology: Based on IEA World Energy Balances regional data, technology deployment surveys, and climate adjustments
sources: IEA World Energy Balances 2024 - Regional energy flows
IEA Energy Efficiency Indicators - Country-specific efficiency data
Enerdata Global Energy Statistical Yearbook - Regional comparisons
metadata.key_insight: China coal plants ~40% efficient (newer fleet), US gas ~48% (high CCGT penetration), developing countries biomass ~12% (traditional cookstoves)

global_baseline.note: These are the global average values from efficiency_factors_corrected.json

notes.coal: 40% - China built massive fleet of supercritical and ultra-supercritical coal plants post-2000. Average efficiency significantly higher than global fleet.
notes.nuclear: 34% - Modern Gen III reactors (AP1000, HPR1000) with slightly higher efficiency
notes.oil: 28% - Lower vehicle efficiency due to older fleet mix, though improving rapidly
notes.biomass: 12% - Rural areas still use traditional biomass for cooking
notes.hydro: 72% - Large modern dams (Three Gorges, etc.) with high efficiency

notes.gas: 48% - High penetration of advanced CCGT plants (~60% of gas generation), high-efficiency furnaces
notes.oil: 32% - More efficient vehicle fleet (CAFE standards), though offset by larger vehicles
notes.coal: 30% - Older subcritical plants dominate (many built 1970s-1980s), below global average
notes.biomass: 25% - Modern wood pellet plants and corn ethanol (E10), minimal traditional biomass

notes.oil: 33% - Most efficient vehicle fleet globally (EU emissions standards, diesel penetration, smaller vehicles)
notes.gas: 47% - Mix of CCGT and high-efficiency condensing boilers for heating
notes.coal: 35% - Remaining coal plants are mostly modern, many countries phasing out
notes.biomass: 22% - Mix of wood pellets for heating/power and some traditional use in Eastern Europe
notes.wind: 71% - Offshore wind farms with larger, more efficient turbines

notes.coal: 28% - Mix of old subcritical (70%) and newer supercritical plants (30%), below global average
notes.biomass: 10% - Dominated by traditional cookstoves in rural areas (600+ million people), very low efficiency
notes.oil: 27% - Older vehicle fleet, two-wheelers (scooters/motorcycles) which are less efficient
notes.nuclear: 32% - Older reactor designs (PHWR), slightly below global average

notes.biomass: 8% - Heavily dominated by traditional biomass (charcoal, firewood for cooking), extremely low efficiency
notes.oil: 26% - Older imported vehicles, limited emissions controls
notes.coal: 29% - South Africa dominates, mix of old and newer plants
notes.hydro: 69% - Mix of large modern dams and smaller older installations

notes.gas: 49% - Highest efficiency gas fleet globally, advanced CCGT, high-efficiency heating
notes.coal: 34% - Modern supercritical plants built post-Fukushima to replace nuclear
notes.nuclear: 34% - Advanced BWR and PWR designs (pre-Fukushima fleet)
notes.oil: 31% - Efficient small vehicles, extensive hybrid penetration (Toyota Prius, etc.)

notes.gas: 40% - Lower efficiency due to: (1) Cold climate increases heating demand (more low-temp heat, less electricity), (2) Older infrastructure, (3) Abundant cheap gas reduces efficiency incentives
notes.nuclear: 32% - Mix of VVER designs, some older RBMK reactors

notes.hydro: 73% - Massive modern dam infrastructure (Itaipu, Belo Monte), very high efficiency
notes.biomass: 20% - Sugarcane ethanol (E25-E100 in flex-fuel vehicles) is relatively efficient, plus some traditional use
notes.oil: 29% - Flex-fuel vehicles common, but ethanol lowers overall petroleum efficiency
27% - Cold climate reduces vehicle efficiency (heating, idling, winter tires), larger vehicles (trucks/SUVs)
notes.gas: 46% - High heating demand (low-temp heat, low exergy), but efficient furnaces
notes.hydro: 72% - Massive modern hydroelectric infrastructure (James Bay, Churchill Falls, etc.)

notes.coal: 36% - Modern supercritical plants, high efficiency fleet
notes.nuclear: 34% - Advanced APR1400 reactors, high capacity factors

notes.coal: 29% - Aging fleet of subcritical plants, low efficiency

calculation_priority.description: How to apply efficiency factors when both regional and temporal variations exist
priority_order: 1. Check if regional override exists for this region and source
2. If yes, use regional value (regional values are 2024 calibrated, already account for time)
3. If no regional override, use temporal formula: base_1965 + (improvement_rate × (year - 1965))
4. If neither regional nor temporal, use global baseline from efficiency_factors_corrected.json
calculation_priority.note: Regional factors take precedence because they're calibrated to actual 2024 fleet characteristics

validation_notes.china_coal_verification: IEA reports China coal fleet ~40% average (2024) vs global ~32%. Verified ✓
validation_notes.us_gas_verification: EIA reports US CCGT capacity factor and efficiency support ~48% weighted average. Verified ✓
validation_notes.india_biomass_verification: IEA reports India traditional biomass use at ~70% of total biomass, efficiency ~10-12%. Verified ✓
validation_notes.africa_biomass_verification: IEA Africa Energy Outlook reports 80%+ traditional biomass, efficiency 8-12%. Verified ✓
